id: Welly Green Thinks - Winter Edition-Odlins Square, Taranaki Wharf 2 Taranaki Street, Waterfront, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Welly Green Thinks - Winter Edition
venue: Odlins Square, Taranaki Wharf 2 Taranaki Street, Waterfront, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Integrating Regenerative Thinking in Adaptation

Join us for a morning discussion aimed at intertwining regenerative thinking with climate adaptation. We will look beyond traditional approaches for addressing climate change including flooding, sea-level rise, urban heat and hydrological impacts. Featuring compelling international case studies, including a hallmark of proactive climate adaptation planning, the Denmark’s iconic “cloudburst” stormwater management. We will challenge attendees to adopt a systemic approach to overcoming climate challenges.
Be part of the conversation that aims to shape sustainable and resilient futures for our communities.

We can’t wait to see you there!

id: July Work Smarter Horowhenua. Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses-102 Liverpool Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: July Work Smarter Horowhenua. Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses
venue: 102 Liverpool Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
description:
This event has been postponed from 17 July to 25 July due to illness. If the postponement date doesn't work for you, please contact info@littleandloud.co.nz.
We’re living in a world where AI adoption is outpacing AI literacy.

Global research shows that three in four employees say they’re using some form of AI at work.
Of these, over 50% say that they hide their AI use on important tasks, and up to 80% say that they are bringing their own AI to work.
More people are using AI, without understanding how it works, without telling their employers that they are using it, without considering the implications, and without knowing how to get the most from the tools they’re using.
This is where AI literacy becomes essential - it’s not just knowing how to use AI tools, it’s about understanding what’s possible, and knowing you don’t need to be technically savvy to use it well.
This practical two-hour in-person workshop is for real people in real businesses; who want to use AI to do more with the resources and tools they already have.
You’ll learn:
What AI actually is, where it’s heading, and why it matters for every kind of business
The best tools for things like admin, planning, performance, content, customer service, and strategy – and what to avoid
How to use AI responsibly: the risks, red flags, and how to keep it ethical
How to “train” AI to sound like you and reflect your business, not bland templates
Step-by-step ways to save yourself hours each week, without sacrificing quality
How to onboard AI into your organisation, and avoid spending hours setting up new tools
Why mindset is everything – and how early adopters are getting ahead fast.
This workshop is built for:
✔️ Both AI beginners and curious dabblers
✔️ Business owners and operators
✔️ SME teams across any sector: retail, trades, services, health, education, not-for-profit, and more
✔️ Anyone who’s been avoiding AI or feeling overwhelmed by the hype.

You’ll walk away with:
A clear, practical understanding of how AI works and how to use it
Proven tools tailored for small businesses
Plug-and-play workflows to save time and reduce mental load
Confidence to use AI without compromising your brand, your values, or your people.
No tech jargon. No hype. Just real-world tools, clear explanations, and fresh thinking for busy people in any business.
*2024 Work Trend Index Annual Report from Microsoft and LinkedIn
Don’t just take our word for it
People from all over the country have attended our AI workshops. Check out some feedback below.
“Loved it, great balanced presentation, lots covered but the pace was good.  Very different to other tech-based presentations without all the 'show-off jargon'.  Lizi was passionate but realistic and gave the pros and cons.  An intentional and thoughtful presentation, thank you.”
“You made such a daunting topic so easy and clear to understand and navigate.”
“Thank you for a fantastic session this morning. I’ve come away with a whole lot more knowledge and food for thought than I was anticipating and feel empowered to start implementing AI tools from today.”

About Lizi Guest (your workshop facilitator)
I’m the founder of Little & Loud, an award-winning public relations and communications agency that’s worked with more than a hundred organisations; from local councils and government agencies to fast-growing businesses and national brands.

I’ve spent my career helping teams work smarter, minimise risks and leverage opportunities that come from doing business in our fast-changing world. I’ve been working with AI tools in real-world settings, working out what actually works and applying these lessons across our broad client base. My focus is on making AI accessible, ethical, and practical for people who don’t have time to waste. After all, tech should make your job easier, not harder.

id: August Work Smarter Horowhenua - Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses-102 Liverpool Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: August Work Smarter Horowhenua - Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses

id: Beyond the Frontlines: an award-winning documentary about Palestinian humanity-65 Dixon Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Beyond the Frontlines: an award-winning documentary about Palestinian humanity
venue: 65 Dixon Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Justice for Palestine and Aotearoa Healthcare Workers for Palestine present Alexandra Dols' award-winning documentary about the impacts of dehumanising violence on Palestinian people. This screening is intended to provide an antidote to the inflammatory anti-Palestinian programming decisions of Doc Edge.
In an environment where language of 'objectivity' and 'neutrality' is used to prop up colonial structures, we are proud to screen a documentary that refuses to buy into this framing. Embark on a journey across Palestine alongside Palestinian psychiatrist Dr. Samah Jabr and discover the resistance and resilience of a people affected by the invisible wounds of war and occupation.
Check out the trailer here.
Net revenue from tickets and donations will be donated to the Gaza Mental Health Foundation: https://www.gazamentalhealth.org/
Arrive from 5.30pm for a 6pm start.
Film is 1 hour, 53 minutes so will finish approximately 8pm, including welcome and introduction.
"The film is brave because it does not claim to be "balanced" through positioning itself an equal distance from the occupier and the occupied of Palestine. Instead, it sheds light on the Palestinian experience and point of view: experiences and views which are usually silenced, distorted, or vilified by mainstream media. The film does not turn away from people who are labeled "controversial" and thus to be avoided and ignored. This film brings together a diversity of interviewees whose strong voices do not fade into an all-too-common passive submission to power and dominance. The interviewees differ ideologically among themselves yet a reunited in their striving for liberation."
Dr. Samah Jabr
“Dr. Samah Jabr is a wise and thoughtful woman. She reflects on the subtle, devastating effect on the Palestinian people of years of brutal occupation. Alexandra Dols’ film shares her insights with us, generous, humane and deeply disturbing. Please see this film.”
Ken Loach

id: FutureVoices 2025-550 High Street, Boulcott, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: FutureVoices 2025
venue: 550 High Street, Boulcott, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
Inspired by Tedx, FutureVoices 2025 will be an evening spotlighting a diverse range of passionate speakers, innovators and leaders sharing their ideas from the Wellington Youth Community on our theme for this year of ‘Redefining Tomorrow’. FutureVoices 2025 is about empowering youth to speak up and take action using their initiatives to better local and wider communities. 
Our event will take place on Friday July 18th, from 6-9pm at St Oran’s College Rutherford Art Centre, 550 High Street, Lower Hutt Wellington. The evening will consist of 8 speakers, from a range of ages between 14 and 27. It is a celebration of youth leadership and achievements; bold ideas and actions, and sharing youth voices and visions for a better, brighter future.

id: The Fantastic 4: First Steps - Fundraiser screening For Short film "Possum"-29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The Fantastic 4: First Steps - Fundraiser screening For Short film "Possum"
venue: 29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The Fantastic 4: First Steps – Fundraiser Screening for Short Film Possum
Join us for a thrilling night of a fresh reboot of The Fantastic Four. Come support our upcoming short film "Possum"
"Possum" is a 3rd year Massey University Short Film that follows a young man entering a ritualistic drinking cult. The film is in the horror/thriller genre, think a grittier Midsummer with elements of Get Out sprinkled in. The story is based on the real NZ drinking game, Possum, where the participants climb a tree with a box of beer and attempt to finish the beers without falling out. 
Whether you're Interested in supporting local student films or in seeing Pedro Pascal, please buy a ticket !!
If you want to learn more about our film -https://www.thearts.co.nz/boosted/projects/possum?tab=about

id: NZLSA Inaugural Alumni Breakfast-107 Customhouse Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: NZLSA Inaugural Alumni Breakfast
venue: 107 Customhouse Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description: Thanks to our friends at IPLS, NZLSA invites all former NZLSA and LSS/LSA Presidents to a complimentary breakfast at Pravda Cafe & Grill in Wellington Central. Join us from 8:30 am onwards on Friday, 26 September, at our Inaugural Alumni Breakfast with NZLSA Patron Justice Glazebrook!

id: Sound Healing Experience with Claudio at Pause Yoga August 23rd of August-28 Moana Road, Days Bay, Lower Hutt 5013, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Sound Healing Experience with Claudio at Pause Yoga August 23rd of August
venue: 28 Moana Road, Days Bay, Lower Hutt 5013, New Zealand
description:
Join us for this special evening of harmonising pure sounds, inspiring music and relaxation in the beautiful Pause Yoga studio in Eastbourne.
Give yourself a peaceful moment and space of quiet awareness. Discover the power of your own voice, mantra and silence working to find inner peace and contentment. Bring an intention, get comfortable and let the sound waves take over. Invite the sound to take you into a journey within, into your heart, to rest, to release physical, mental and emotional tension. Surrender to the sound of Gong, Tibetan and Crystal Bowls, Native American flutes, Harmonium, Sitar ,Esraj, Bells etc..
Claudio brings high quality amplification so you can feel the sound in your body and take into a immersive experience.Feel free to bring a pillow and blanket to assure comfort. 
About Claudio: Claudio is a 3rd generation Multinstrumentalist Musician from Mexico City now based in Wellington. Claudio comes from a musicians family he started playing music since very early years. When he finished music school as a classical guitarist he moved to Montreal, Canada and explored new genres such a Jazz, World Music, and Spiritual Music. Traveling he discovered Indian Music and the Yoga Tradition and they became a very important influence on his career and lifestyle, and allowed him to study Music and Yoga with teachers in Europe and Asia. He learnt to play the Tibetan Singing Bowls in Kathmandu Nepal and Varanasi India.He explored many instruments and music styles such as Classical Guitar, Sitar, Esraj, Bansuri, Harmonium, Flutes, Gongs and Voice.Claudio is an active Sound Healing practitioner and performer. He has been playing the Tibetan bowls for more than 10 years now

id: An Invitation to Love-211 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: An Invitation to Love
venue: 211 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
You're invited!

Cantoris is excited to announce our second concert for 2025: An Invitation to Love. 
Directed by Ingrid Schofield | Accompanied by Heather Easting

Romantic love, sacred love, and even friendship will be captured through the works of Tallis, Ireland, Whitacre, and the shimmering centrepiece of Lauridsen's Nocturnes. New works by Wellington's own Jonathan Berkahn sit alongside a vibrant selection of madrigals that capture the joy, longing, and playful spirit that love inspires.

We cannot wait to perform and share our love of this music with you.

🕒 Sunday 7th September | 3pm
 📍  St Peter's Anglican Church | 211 Willis Street, Pōneke

id: Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band-81 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
venue: 81 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!
If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.
This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.
Discounted online tickets are available until midnight on September 26th. Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only). Keep an eye on the Facebook event for updates.
—
Doors open 7:30pm
Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.
Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.
Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.
Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.
Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson-1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson
venue: 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The next concert in our series presents a new project by Dave Wilson titled Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation. This project brings together a collective of musicians from across the music communities of Pōneke in an invitation to explore the expansive possibilities for what liberation might sound like.

Free, Free draws from legacies of musical collectivity, and celebrates a commitment to both collaboration and the distinct expression of each individual.
Ranging from contemplative minimalism to ecstatic ensemble energy and body-moving grooves, the music of Free, Free invites musicians and other listeners to tend to each moment, making their own offerings to shape the collective sound.

Dave Wilson is a saxophonist, clarinettist, composer, producer, and interdisciplinary scholar. His music bridges avant-garde and experimental music with various groove-oriented styles from the worlds of jazz, R&B, electronic music, and more.
 
With his 2023 album Ephemeral, described as “quite spiritually intense music” by The Guardian, he was a finalist for Te Manu Taki Tautito o te Tau | Best Jazz Artist at the Aotearoa Music Awards, and for the APRA Best Jazz Composition Award. Before relocating to Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington in 2016, Dave grew up in the Chicago area, lived for a decade in Los Angeles, and spent several stints living in Skopje, North Macedonia.
 
Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation
Dave Wilson, Tyaan Singh – alto saxophone
Louisa Williamson – tenor saxophone
Monique Lapins, Mana Waiariki – violin
Ken Ichinose – cello
Kaito Walley, Natania Ngawhau – trombone
Ben Hunt – trumpet
Daniel Hayles, Andrew Faleatua – piano and keyboard
Phoebe Johnson – bass
Callum Allardice – guitar
Hikurangi Schaverien-Kaa – drums

The performance will begin with an opening set by Flute Journeys, an offbeat mass flute ensemble with the self-described playing abilities of 5–12-year-olds, embodying a form of liberation in music.

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.
Thanks to CNZ for their generous support.

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells-Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells
venue: Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The seventh concert in our series is a new suite of music by Tāmaki Makaurau composer, performer, and educator; Callum Passells.
For the Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Callum brings new music for his ensemble LCR, an ensemble which features three identical saxophone trios (sax, bass, and drums) that play with and against each other in a kaleidoscopic and often explosive fashion. The new pieces commissioned for this series continue to stretch at the fabric of jazz and improvised forms, and are inspired by Morton Feldman, Lennie Tristano, Henry Threadgill and Sly Stone.
Callum has been deeply involved in the New Zealand jazz and improvised music scene for over a decade, and is a busy freelancer in the wider music community in Auckland. He has performed with Aldous Harding, Hans Pucket, the Exploding Rainbow Orchestra, the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra, among many others. In 2021, Callum was commissioned to compose a large-scale work 'Solid Spirit, Liquid Body' for the Wellington Jazz Festival. He is currently completing a Master of Music degree at the University of Auckland, where he also teaches saxophone.
The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.

id: The Tempests EP Release-62 Bell Street, Featherston 5710, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The Tempests EP Release
venue: 62 Bell Street, Featherston 5710, New Zealand
description:
The Tempests
Vocalists Jade Eru and Lynley Christoffersen weave vocal magic born from a shared experience and bond that only comes from years of singing together to create a sound greater than the sum of its parts. 
Soulful, sweet harmonies skillfully backed by a band of accomplished yet understated musicians.
Drummer Richard Te One, bassist Miklin Halstead, guitarists Chris Armour and Rob Matthews form the backbone of The Tempests. Drawing from a deep well of musical knowledge and influences, their supportive and tenacious musicianship help to swell the sound of the Tempests and serve the song. 
The Tempests have crafted timeless melodies and emotionally rich songs into vivid aural tapestries.
Hamish Graham.
Hamish has often been found on a baritone guitar with Wellington stalwarts Hobnail, or fronting his own cello-pop ensemble, Milkthistle.
Hamish brings his distinctive take on the world around us with lush and lively approaches to well-crafted songs that follow an arc of experiences and emotions.

id: Kim Churchill (Australia) LIVE at St Peter's Village Hall | Paekakariki-Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Kim Churchill (Australia) LIVE at St Peter's Village Hall | Paekakariki
venue: Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand
description:
Experience Kim Churchill Live – For the First Time Ever in New Zealand!
Beloved for his soulful storytelling and breathtaking live shows, Kim Churchill is finally bringing his dynamic sound across the Tasman. This marks Kim’s debut tour of Aotearoa, and you will have the rare opportunity to witness his mesmerizing performances in intimate venues around the country. With his unique blend of folk, blues, and layered acoustic textures, these shows promise to be unforgettable nights of music, heart, and connection!
November 30 @ St Peter's Village Hall, Paekakariki
2:30pm doors / 3:00pm start
Over the past 12 years Kim has achieved some incredible things as a professional musician. He’s recognised as much internationally as he is in Australia, having performed headline shows, festivals and supports alike all over the planet. Notable performances include Glastonbury, Splendour in the Grass, Falls Festival, Montreal Jazz, Telluride Blues, and supports with Milky Chance, Billy Bragg, Michael Franti and Nahko and the Medicine People,
Known for his magnetic, dynamic stage presence, Kim unites lyrical artistry with fierce vocals; he is a sonic architect – using his guitar to create landscapes, which animate his lyrics. Don’t miss your chance to see Kim Churchill up close, as he delivers the full force of his artistry – weaving raw emotion with technical brilliance and passion. Whether you’ve followed his journey from afar or are discovering his music for the first time, this tour is set to be a celebration of song and spirit from one of Australia’s most compelling live performers.
A Message From Kim
I feel like I’m just beginning. Which is strange because for the last 15 years I’ve been living in the back of a camper van playing gigs and chasing this crazy dream. I grew up in a small town on the east coast of Australia called Merimbula. We’re mainly known for Surfing, Oysters and Whale Watching. I started busking at local farmers markets when I was 15 and had a fake ID so I could play some pubs around my area. I set off in a van straight after high school to chase my dreams and surf my way across the country.
In that first year I was lucky to win the Byron Bluesfest Busking comp and became Folk Artist of the Year and the National Folk Festival. This led to some incredible adventures to Japan, North America and Europe. I busked all over the world and bought 2 more camper vans on different continents. I have three now and each year I fly between them playing festivals and seeking the far corners of world and all the beautiful places I can play music I was lucky enough to become good friends with Billy Bragg from England early on and he taught me a lot about longevity and living as an artist for the long haul. He took me across America, Canada, Europe and England In a tour bus for a whole year and we played Glastonbury Music Festival together. After that time, I wrote a song called ‘Window to the Sky’. It was on an album called ‘Silence/Win’ which really helped me step up a few notches. I signed major record deals with Warner, Atlantic Records (UK) and Universal (Europe). ‘Window to the Sky’ was the most played song on triple J at that time and it went on to be 42 in the Hottest 100 and is Platinum in Australia, Gold in Canada and Germany .and has over 50 million streams!
I manage myself these days and am at the wheel of this beautiful ship. I have amazing people around the world who have become dear friends over the years and help me on my path. But I’m so so proud to be an artist in control of my own journey. Big thanks to Billy! for setting such a fine example
A few years ago, I started waking up before Dawn and creating a little sunrise ritual out of my song writing. Every morning I get up at about 5am and light some candles and write music. This inspired my last album ‘Dawn Sounds’ which came out in January 2023. I toured it around the world as an independent self managed artist.and sold over 12 thousand tickets and played 149 concerts Now I'm back in Australia in my camper van writing this from a small town on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia. I’m have a new album coming out October 11th and am. excited tour it all around the world. It’s called ‘It’s Lovely To Have You Here’

id: One for the Road - a queer poetry showcase-8 Chews Lane, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: One for the Road - a queer poetry showcase
venue: 8 Chews Lane, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
An intoxicating night of poetry reading at elixir, Pōneke's most enchanting boutique cocktail bar, featuring a diverse cast of queer poets including special guest essa may ranapiri! Come enjoy some fine food and drink and equally fine writing in the heart of the city, the Sunday after Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, for a classy way to top off a weekend of literary events in style.
Doors open 6pm, poetry begins 6:30pm.

id: Bookmark Big Night Out-21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu 5032, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Bookmark Big Night Out
venue: 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu 5032, New Zealand
description:
Voice, music, and visuals collide in an electric celebration of people, story, and place.

Bookmark Big Night Out brings together a powerhouse lineup of musicians and storytellers: Mocean (Julia Truscott, Himiona Grace & Janet Holborow), Hinemoana Baker, Te Kahu Rolleston, and Jess Deacon, with stunning visuals by Phil Simmonds.
Experience Kāpiti storytelling like never before.

18+
Tickets are limited so get in quick!
No door sales!
Ngā mihi to Valley Audio for sponsoring this event.

id: Messiah-71 Woburn Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Messiah
venue: 71 Woburn Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
Experience the uplifting power of Handel’s Messiah this winter with a special afternoon performance at 3pm on Saturday, 19 July 2025, at St James' Anglican Church, Lower Hutt. 
This unique collaboration brings together two of Wellington’s most respected choirs: the Festival Singers, directed by Ingrid Schoenfeld, and the St Mary of the Angels Choir, directed by William McElwee. 
Acclaimed organist Jonathan Berkahn will accompany the performance, adding his signature depth and colour to the work’s stirring arias and choruses.
Ingrid Schoenfeld, a concert pianist, has led the Festival Singers since 2019, earning praise for her warm, engaging conducting style and commitment to musical excellence. 
William McElwee, Director of Music at St Mary of the Angels, is a multifaceted musician known for drawing outstanding vocalism from his choirs and stretching them musically. 
Jonathan Berkahn, a seasoned performer and educator with a PhD in musicology, brings a wealth of experience as an accompanist, soloist, and chamber musician, enriching the performance with his expertise.
While traditionally associated with Christmas and Easter, this mid-winter performance of Messiah offers a refreshing opportunity to experience its radiant choruses and sparkling solos in a new light. 
The comfortable setting and lovely acoustics of St James' Anglican Church make it an ideal venue for a winter afternoon concert – a popular choice during the colder months. 
Featuring talented soloists from both choirs, this concert promises to be a heart-warming highlight of the season.

id: Brooklyn School Fundraiser - The Goonies at the Penthouse-205 Ohiro Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Brooklyn School Fundraiser - The Goonies at the Penthouse
venue: 205 Ohiro Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
description:
Join us for a nostalgic adventure to the cinema with our fundraiser screening of THE GOONIES!
A group of young misfits called The Goonies discover an ancient map and set out on an adventure to find a legendary pirate's long-lost treasure. Starring a very young Sean Astin and Josh Brolin!
Tickets are $25 each and all profits go towards Brooklyn School’s playground upgrade for the youngest students (Tui classrooms).
THE GOONIES (1985) is rated PG with a content warning for coarse language. There are also some mildly scary scenes.
This event is General Admission - come early if you want the best seat in the house!
Parking
There is a pay and display car park located on the south side of the cinema building on Ohiro Road.  You can also pay for the southside (downhill) carpark inside the cinema at the tills.  Not the north side park. The carpark is camera operated by Smart Compliance Management. If you have any issues with parking please do not hesitate to email office@penthousecinema.co.nz 
Otherwise - there is limited on street parking around the venue.

id: Falling Walls Lab Aotearoa New Zealand 2025-11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Falling Walls Lab Aotearoa New Zealand 2025
venue: 11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Royal Society Te Apārangi invites you to attend Falling Walls Lab Aotearoa New Zealand 2025 on
Thursday 7 August where 21 participants from Aotearoa New Zealand and the Pacific Island Nations will pitch their innovative breakthrough idea for the chance to represent the region and compete at the Falling Walls Lab Global Finale in Berlin. 
Participants will have 3 minutes to showcase their innovative research, scientific idea, or evidence-based initiative, and how it could make a difference for society.
Attend this FREE event to hear the participants pitch their breakthrough ideas to the Falling Walls Lab Aotearoa New Zealand Jury and be inspired by these students and early-career professionals!

Morning Session - Hōtaka Programme
11.30am Mihi welcome and introductory remarks
11.45am Pitch presentations (participants 1-10)
12.45pm Kai a te Rānui Lunch
Afternoon Session - Hōtaka Programme
1.45pm Pitch presentations (participants 11-21)
2.45pm Networking break / Kaiwhakawā Jury evaluation session
3.45pm Award ceremony / Group photo and closing remarks
4.15–6.00pm Networking and connecting reception

Kaitautoko Partners
Falling Walls Lab Aotearoa New Zealand is hosted by Royal Society Te Apārangi with support from the German Embassy in Wellington, the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment and EURAXESS Australia & New Zealand.

About Falling Walls
Falling Walls Labs are organised by independent partners of Falling Walls Foundation across the globe. The winners of each Lab travel to Berlin for the Falling Wall Lab Global Finale run by the Falling Walls Foundation.
Falling Walls is inspired by the world-changing event of the fall of the Berlin Wall on 9 November 1989, with the question at every Falling Walls gathering: Which walls will fall next?
 ***For event enquiries, please contact the organisers at events@royalsociety.org.nz

id: WellyForge#3, 20th August 2025-118 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: WellyForge#3, 20th August 2025
venue: 118 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Join us to help progress Wellington by bringing together science, tech & investors from across the city into an informal, fun and informative meet-up. The goal of the event is that you learn something new, meet someone new, have fun and we all start forging new paths ahead for Wellington.
The August event will have see us ask the mayoral candidates for Wellington about their plans for the economy and how they see tech & science playing into them. The event will be MCed by Wellington science journalist Peter Griffin, and, at this point, we have three candidates confirmed:
Andrew Little
Karl Tiefenbacher
Ray Chung
We won't know until 1st August who the final candidates are.
The venue is bohemian bookstore, Undercurrent, a perfect venue for story telling but tickets are limited - so please reserve yours, but if you do end up not being able to come please return the ticket!
Register for regular emails from WellyForge

id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Military Tales from the Services Section (Aug 2025)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Military Tales from the Services Section (Aug 2025)
venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
Military Tales from the Services Area
Come and hear tales from our military history.
The tour duration is 1 hour 30mins. The tour mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

id: House of Marama Vogue Night | 22nd Aug 8pm-63 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: House of Marama Vogue Night | 22nd Aug 8pm
venue: 63 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The Mesmerising Kiki HOUSE OF MARAMA will be hosting a VOGUE NIGHT this August!
Come and get your life on Friday 22nd August at Ivy Bar & Cabaret!
TICKETS
GA $20 + Online Fees (LIMITED)
Extra koha Tickets $25 (min.) + Online Fees (LIMITED)
$25 Doorsales until Midnight (LIMITED) Cash or Eftpos.
WHEN Friday 22nd August (2025) — Doors open from 8.00pm, Categories start from 9:30pm.
WHERE Ivy Bar & Cabaret, Wellington (NZ) R18+ 
CATEGORIES
OTA FACE (trophy)
OTA BODY (trophy)
OTA RUNWAY (trophy)
SHAKE VS SHAKE (trophy)
OTA PERFORMANCE (trophy)
OVERALL THEME: COME AS YOU ARE
* Refer to the 'Ballroom Terminology' section below and our instagram post for more details about each category.

JUDGES, CHANTERS & DJ
MOTHER ROME' MARAMA
FQ GODMOTHER HIBISCUS MARAMA
FQ ANTHEA MARAMA
ORIJAH MARAMA (MC/Commentator)
KAYUHSEEYUH (DJ)
Follow our Instagram @houseofmarama to keep up to date with our events.
--------
Ballroom is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Ballroom check out this link: 
https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. 
The HOUSE OF MARAMA honours the whenua in which this event is able to take place on, belonging to the true sovereigns: 
Te Ātiawa iwi. We also stand in solidarity with indigenous peoples across the world facing injustice. 
TOITŪ TE TIRITI
FREE PALESTINE
FREE CONGO
FREE WEST PAPUA
FREE KANAKY
FREE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE EVERYWHERE. 
LAND BACK.
Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @wlgballroom on Instagram.
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on any of our socials for any questions or concerns you may have.
---------
BALLROOM TERMINOLOGY*
OTA = Open to All, not limited to a specific gender identity/expression, or category style.
SHAKE VS SHAKE = We wanna see you shake that ass, shake that hair, shake those thighs. We want to see why YOU have the best shake.
FACE = Serve FACE, highlighting your structure, eyes, teeth, skin and nose. Makeup allowed.
BODY =The ability to sell your confidence in yourself, specifically through your body (not through sex appeal).
PERFORMANCE = Performing and battling in a style of Vogue (Old Way, New Way, or Vogue Fem).

id: New Zealand Book Awards for Children & Young Adults Ceremony 2025-55-59 Thorndon Quay, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: New Zealand Book Awards for Children & Young Adults Ceremony 2025
venue: 55-59 Thorndon Quay, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Buy your tickets now for the 2025 New Zealand Book Awards for Children and Young Adults to join the celebration of the best books of the year for young New Zealand readers. You’ll get to meet the finalists and applaud the winners at an exuberant awards ceremony in the characterful Pipitea Marae on Wednesday 13 August.
Forty-seven gifted children’s writers, illustrators and translators are finalists in this year’s awards. Their achievements will be acknowledged on the night by publishers, politicians, booksellers, librarians, media and supporters of the children’s literature community. Members of the public are welcome to purchase tickets too.
Winners in the 2025 New Zealand Book Awards for Children and Young Adults will be announced in six categories: Picture Book (the BookHub Award), Junior Fiction (the Wright Family Foundation Esther Glen Award), Young Adult Fiction, Non-Fiction, Illustration (the Russell Clark Award) and Te Reo Māori (the Wright Family Foundation Te Kura Pounamu Awards).
One of the category winners will be named the night’s supreme winner of the Margaret Mahy Book of the Year. The judges will also present the NZSA Best First Book award to a previously unpublished author or illustrator from a shortlist of five titles.
All guests with tickets are also invited to the post-ceremony function in the Pipitea’s wharekai, with food and refreshments served from 8.30pm to 10.00pm.
This is a popular event with a limited number of seats, so book your place today and enjoy this wonderful celebration of Aotearoa’s very best children’s literature.
Facebook
Instagram
Tiktok

id: Unity Book Club August 2025 | Before the Winter Ends-57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Unity Book Club August 2025 | Before the Winter Ends
venue: 57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
About the book: 
In the cold Wellington winter, Omar’s grades are slipping, his mum is unwell and his best friend is growing distant. Two decades earlier in Mogadishu, Asha and Yasser are falling in love and starting to build a life together while a burgeoning war threatens to take it away.
Before the Winter Ends explores the relationship between mother and son across Aotearoa New Zealand, Somalia and Egypt as they search for understanding and try to bridge the distance between them. Khadro Mohamed’s debut novel is a stark portrayal of how the past illuminates the present and how grief shapes a family.

Melissa and Eden will be hosting our monthly book club to discuss some of the excellent recently released books.

In July we will be discussing Before the Winter Ends by Khadro Mohamed.

We have limited tickets available so grab a ticket sooner rather then later and tell your friends and whānau.

Drinks and snacks provided. If you have any specific allergies, let us know and send an email.

If you have any further queries send us an email to wellington@unitybooks.co.nz and address it to Melissa.

id: It's the Little Websites that Count-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: It's the Little Websites that Count
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
For most current technology, it is assumed that the user is always online and has access to unlimited data. But this assumption is only valid for regions with the infrastructure to support the internet. As more vital communications and services transition into websites, how do we make sure that these services are still usable in areas with only low bandwidth internet or during natural disasters? In this event we will start a discussion about developing smaller websites for accessibility in Aotearoa.
About the host
Vic Roberts is a computer vision scientist who works with machine learning in medical imaging. In her spare time, she likes to ponder about how to tackle the digital divide.

id: Awa After Dark: Spotlighting at Korokoro Stream, Belmont Regional Park-Cornish Street, Korokoro, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Awa After Dark: Spotlighting at Korokoro Stream, Belmont Regional Park
venue: Cornish Street, Korokoro, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand
description:
Explore your local awa with freshwater experts from our Wai Connection team at this spotlighting event at Korokoro Stream. With your gumboots and a torch, head off on an evening hīkoi to your local waterway to ‘spotlight’ and observe freshwater species in their natural habitat. Learn about the health of our waterways, freshwater conservation efforts in your neighbourhood, and some of the ways that you could become a kaitiaki of your local awa.
Awa After Dark events take place in the early evening, they’re perfect for the whole whānau.
This event is free, but bookings are essential. These events are very popular, please let us know if you have booked and can no longer make it so we can reallocate your spot.
Outdoor event:  This event is outdoors, please dress appropriately (gumboots and warm clothing recommended). If the weather is really bad, we'll let you know we’re cancelling via the email you've provided us.
Location: The streams we spotlight often don't have an 'address'. On the day before the event, we'll email you all the details you need to find our exact meeting location on the night.
What is spotlighting? Ever played spotlight with a fish? Heaps of our native freshwater critters are nocturnal. Scientists often visit freshwater areas at nighttime with a torch, it’s the best time to see exactly who’s living in our awa!
What is Wai Connection? Wai Connection is a national programme delivered by Mountains to Sea Wellington aimed at connecting local communities to their waterways to improve them. We support communities and mana whenua with the knowledge, tools and expertise to monitor and care for their local freshwater places.
